items.title: Canada's housing shortage is a leading cause of our affordability crisis.

description.html:
• Housing starts in Canada peaked in the 1970s, even though our population has doubled since then.

  • The rental vacancy rate across the country is at a record low of 1.9%—it’s even lower in the most expensive cities.

  • Low vacancy rates drive large rent increases. When vacancy rates are high, rent hikes slow down or even reverse.

  • There is no massive secret supply of vacant homes. In fact, Canada has the fewest homes per person in the entire G7.
description.markdown:
- Housing starts in Canada [peaked in the 1970s](<https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=3410012601>), even though our population has doubled since then.

- The rental vacancy rate across the country is at [a record low of 1.9%](<https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/-/media/sites/cmhc/professional/housing-markets-data-and-research/market-reports/rental-market-report/rental-market-report-2022-en.ashx#:~:text=%E2%80%9CNational%20rental%20market%20conditions%20tightened,demand%20surging%20in%20many%20markets.%E2%80%9D&text=Growth%20in%20demand%20outpaced%20strong,rate's%20lowest%20level%20since%202001.>)—it’s even lower in the most expensive cities.

- Low vacancy rates [drive large rent increases](<https://doodles.mountainmath.ca/blog/2018/11/28/vacancy-rate-and-rent-change/>). When vacancy rates are high, rent hikes slow down or even reverse.

- There is [no massive secret supply of vacant homes](<https://doodles.mountainmath.ca/blog/2019/08/19/running-on-empties/>). In fact, Canada has [the fewest homes per person](https://businesscouncilab.com/insights-category/economic-insights/weekly-econ-minute-canada-housing-shortage/#:~:text=In%20fact%2C%20Canada%20has%20the,480%20dwellings%20per%201%2C000%20residents) in the entire G7.

items.title: Municipal regulations have strangled Canada’s housing supply.

description.html:
• Zoning rules prohibit high density housing on the majority of residential land, even in cities with acute housing shortages.

  • Most apartments require a rezoning, an expensive and risky process that requires a public hearing and vote at City Council.

  • Floor space maximums and setback requirements greatly reduce the amount of housing that can be built on a given plot of land.

  • Parking minimums add significant expense to new housing, with each underground stall adding upwards of $100k to construction costs.

  • Development charges have ballooned far beyond reasonable levels, adding as much as $90k to home prices in the GTA.
description.markdown:
- Zoning rules [prohibit high density housing on the majority of residential land](<https://www.datalabto.ca/a-visual-guide-to-detached-houses-in-5-canadian-cities/>), even in cities with acute housing shortages.

- Most apartments require a rezoning, an expensive and risky process that requires a public hearing and vote at City Council.

- Floor space maximums and setback requirements greatly reduce the amount of housing that can be built on a given plot of land.

- Parking minimums add significant expense to new housing, with each underground stall adding upwards of $100k to construction costs.

- Development charges have ballooned far beyond reasonable levels, adding as much as [$90k to home prices in the GTA](<https://ir.lib.uwo.ca/urbancentre-reports/8/>).


<!-- -->

items.title: Building more market rate housing reduces housing costs and is crucial for broad affordability

description.html:
• Even expensive new housing helps with broad affordability by creating chains of vacancies throughout the housing market. People who move into a "luxury condos" are opening up vacancies in more affordable homes elsewhere.

  • Today’s new “luxury” housing will form our future affordable housing stock. The affordable apartments we have today were expensive when they were first built.

  • This is not trickle-down economics. Allowing more market housing does not cost municipalities anything (in fact, it generates revenue).
description.markdown:
* Even expensive new housing helps with broad affordability by creating chains of vacancies throughout the housing market. People who move into a "luxury condos" are opening up vacancies in more affordable homes elsewhere.

* Today’s new “luxury” housing will form our future affordable housing stock. The affordable apartments we have today were expensive when they were first built.

* This is not trickle-down economics. Allowing more market housing does not cost municipalities anything (in fact, it generates revenue).

items.title: Urban sprawl is fiscally and environmentally unsustainable.

description.html:
• Per capita emissions in low-density suburbs are up to 3 times higher than in urban areas
  • Outward sprawl destroys irreplaceable natural habitats and farmland
  • Apartment buildings are inherently much more energy efficient than low density homes
  • New suburbs typically cost much more to service than they generate in revenue.
description.markdown:
* Per capita emissions in low-density suburbs are [up to 3 times higher than in urban areas](https://res.cloudinary.com/dbnijop5c/image/upload/v1696959238/Toronto_carbon_footprints_charts_0_mrtv82.png)
* Outward sprawl destroys irreplaceable natural habitats and farmland
* Apartment buildings are inherently much more energy efficient than low density homes
* New suburbs typically [cost much more to service than they generate in revenue.](https://www.gtyeg.ca/finances)

items.title: Row houses, multiplexes, lodging homes and low-rise apartments should be permitted in all neighbourhoods as of right.

description.html:
• "Missing Middle" housing projects are often killed by slow, expensive and risky rezoning processes.

  • Affordable housing projects are impacted the most and often face significant pushback at public hearings.
description.markdown:
- "Missing Middle" housing projects are often killed by slow, expensive and risky rezoning processes.

- Affordable housing projects are impacted the most and often face significant pushback at public hearings.


<!-- -->

items.title: Mid-rise and high-rise apartments should be permitted as of right within walking distance of frequent transit and within active transit-distance of major job centres.

description.html:
• Long and expensive rezoning processes inflate land costs and adds significant delays to building new housing projects.

  • It is unjust to restrict multifamily housing to land adjacent to major roads with poor air quality and harmful levels of noise pollution.
description.markdown:
* Long and expensive rezoning processes inflate land costs and adds significant delays to building new housing projects.

* It is unjust to restrict multifamily housing to land adjacent to major roads with poor air quality and harmful levels of noise pollution.

items.title: Restrictions on setbacks, floorplate need to be relaxed and parking minimums abolished.

description.html:
• Even when apartments are technically permitted, municipalities employ a suite of “poison pills” that make them far more expensive to build than they need to be.

  • Parking minimums add significant expense to new housing, with each underground stall adding upwards of $100k to construction costs.

  • Overzealous setbacks, floor space maximums and angular plane requirements substantially reduce the number of homes that can be built. They also result in inefficient and awkward layouts, prioritizing aesthetic preferences over the quality of life of future residents.
description.markdown:
- Even when apartments are technically permitted, municipalities employ a suite of “poison pills” that make them far more expensive to build than they need to be.

- Parking minimums add significant expense to new housing, with each underground stall adding upwards of $100k to construction costs.

- Overzealous setbacks, floor space maximums and angular plane requirements substantially reduce the number of homes that can be built. They also result in inefficient and awkward layouts, prioritizing aesthetic preferences over the quality of life of future residents.


<!-- -->

items.title: Municipalities should not charge onerous fees on new high-density housing.

description.html:
• Charging high fees on new homes reduces home construction and increases housing costs.

  • New high-density housing generates far more tax revenue than it costs to service in the long run. As such, it is not reasonable or fair to make new residents pay for increased public infrastructure and services up-front when they will be paying full property taxes thereafter.

  • Fees should be consistent and predictable, both between similar projects within a specific city but also across cities within a province.

  • Development fees should not be used to avoid property tax increases.
description.markdown:
- Charging high fees on new homes [reduces home construction and increases housing costs](https://ir.lib.uwo.ca/urbancentre-reports/8/).

- New high-density housing generates far more tax revenue than[ it costs to service in the long run](<https://lede-admin.usa.streetsblog.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/46/2015/03/sprawlurban.jpg>). As such, it is not reasonable or fair to make new residents pay for increased public infrastructure and services up-front when they will be paying full property taxes thereafter.

- Fees should be consistent and predictable, both between similar projects within a specific city but also across cities within a province.

- Development fees should not be used to avoid property tax increases.


<!-- -->

items.title: Higher orders of government need to step in and intervene as municipalities are not making necessary reforms in a timely manner.

description.html:
• Federal and provincial governments must set adequate targets for adding net new housing and divide these targets among municipalities.

  • Incentive programs and/or penalties should be used to hold municipalities accountable to these targets.

  • Provincial governments should not be afraid to make unilateral changes to land use regulations—like Bill 47 in BC.
description.markdown:
* Federal and provincial governments must set adequate targets for adding net new housing and divide these targets among municipalities.

* Incentive programs and/or penalties should be used to hold municipalities accountable to these targets.

* Provincial governments should not be afraid to make unilateral changes to land use regulations—[like Bill 47 in BC](https://news.gov.bc.ca/releases/2023HOUS0063-001748).

items.title: We need more deeply affordable housing, but to achieve sufficient scale requires funding from provincial and federal governments.

description.html:
It is unlikely that the private market will provide adequate housing for all needs, even with (realistic) subsidies.

Housing is becoming unaffordable even for professionals making median salaries. Building subsidized housing for middle income earners is not scalable and will most likely function as a lottery for a few lucky winners.

The need for social housing does not arise from building market-rate housing; it is a societal responsibility and should be paid for from general revenues, not pushed onto newcomers and the young.
description.markdown:
It is unlikely that the private market will provide adequate housing for all needs, even with (realistic) subsidies. 

Housing is becoming unaffordable even for professionals making median salaries. Building subsidized housing for middle income earners is not scalable and will most likely function as a lottery for a few lucky winners.

The need for social housing does not arise from building market-rate housing; it is a societal responsibility and should be paid for from general revenues, not pushed onto newcomers and the young.

description.html:
Aim for strong, clear rules to reduce the need for long negotiations about individual sites and arbitrary decision-making.

The vast majority of consultation should be part of proactive community planning. Resulting community plans should provide clear, reliable requirements for anyone who wants to build, with no arbitrary decision-making and as few discretionary parameters as possible.

The consultation process should be additive, with less focus on density and more on quality placemaking, services and infrastructure. Where consultation is needed, governments should assess demographics and adjust methods to ensure that the voices being heard represent the whole community and future residents.
description.markdown:
Aim for strong, clear rules to reduce the need for long negotiations about individual sites and arbitrary decision-making. 

The vast majority of consultation should be part of proactive community planning. Resulting community plans should provide clear, reliable requirements for anyone who wants to build, with no arbitrary decision-making and as few discretionary parameters as possible. 

The consultation process should be additive, with less focus on density and more on quality placemaking, services and infrastructure. Where consultation is needed, governments should assess demographics and adjust methods to ensure that the voices being heard represent the whole community and future residents.

en.heading: Who We Are
en.subheading: More Homes Canada is a coalition of local housing advocacy groups. Together, we are fighting to end Canada’s housing shortage.

subheading.html: Municipal regulations have strangled housing construction across Canada for decades. To end the housing crisis, we need to eliminate the ruinous policies at its root.
subheading.markdown: Municipal regulations have strangled housing construction across Canada for decades. To end the housing crisis, we need to eliminate the ruinous policies at its root.

description.html: Homes are a necessity, not a nuisance. Townhouses, multiplexes and apartments should be allowed in far more places without a long and risky rezoning.
description.markdown: Homes are a necessity, not a nuisance. Townhouses, multiplexes and apartments should be allowed in far more places without a long and risky rezoning.

description.html: Setbacks, floorplate restrictions and parking minimums drive up building costs and kill new housing projects. Easing these regulations will help market and non-market housing.
description.markdown: Setbacks, floorplate restrictions and parking minimums drive up building costs and kill new housing projects. Easing these regulations will help market and non-market housing.

description.html: There are too many veto rights on new housing. Local concerns are important but they do not trump the need for housing.
description.markdown: There are too many veto rights on new housing. Local concerns are important but they do not trump the need for housing.

description.html: Deeply affordable housing requires deep subsidies. Federal and provincial governments need to step up and provide this funding.
description.markdown: Deeply affordable housing requires deep subsidies. Federal and provincial governments need to step up and provide this funding.

en.heading: Who We Are
en.subheading: More Homes Canada is a coalition of housing advocacy groups from across the country. Together, we are fighting to end Canada’s housing shortage.

items.title: Canada has a massive housing shortage that is a leading the root cause of our affordability crisis.

description.html: Canada built more homes in the mid 1970s than it has any time since, even though our population has doubled.
description.markdown: Canada built more homes in the mid 1970s than it has any time since, even though our population has doubled.

items.title: Municipal regulations have strangled Canada’s housing supply

description.html: Generally our services range from $100-500 depending on your needs.
description.markdown: Generally our services range from $100-500 depending on your needs.

items.title: Building more market rate housing reduces housing costs and is crucial for broad affordability

description.html:
Today’s new “luxury” housing will form our future affordable housing stock. Through filtering, even expensive new homes reduce housing costs across the spectrum, both in the near term and in the future.

According to studies of vacancy chains, new market-rate housing helps lower income households as higher income households move from existing homes to new homes. (Example: previously affordable used car prices exploded during Covid supply chain disruptions, and fell after supply chains for new cars were restored)

This is not trickle-down. Allowing more market housing does not cost municipalities anything and creates physical vacancies. Examples from Auckland and Minnesota
description.markdown:
Today’s new “luxury” housing will form our future affordable housing stock.
Through filtering, even expensive new homes reduce housing costs across the spectrum, both in the near term and in the future.

 According to studies of vacancy chains, new market-rate housing helps lower income households as higher income households move from existing homes to new homes.  (Example: previously affordable used car prices exploded during Covid supply chain disruptions, and fell after supply chains for new cars were restored)

This is not trickle-down. Allowing more market housing does not cost municipalities anything and creates physical vacancies.
Examples from Auckland and Minnesota

content.markdown:

## Heading 2

### Heading 3
